subsection.title: Definitions

notation.description: The intersection of A and B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The intersection of A and B (denoted by A \cap B) is the set of all elements that are in both A and B. That is, A \cap B = \{x:x \in A \textrm{ and } x \in B\}.

ul.li: Solving a system of simultaneous equations such as x + y = 7 and x - y = 3 can be viewed as an intersection. Let A = \{(x,y): x + y = 7, x,y \in \mathbb{R}\} and B = \{(x,y): x - y = 3, x,y\in \mathbb{R}\}. These two sets are lines in the plane and their intersection, A \cap B = \{(5, 2)\}, is the solution to the system.

li.p: If A = \{3, 5, 9\} and B = \{-5, 8\}, then A\cap B =\emptyset.

statement.p: Two sets are disjoint if they have no elements in common. That is, A and B are disjoint if A \cap B = \emptyset.

notation.description: The union of A and B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The union of A and B (denoted by A \cup B) is the set of all elements that are in A or in B or in both A and B. That is, A\cup B= \{x:x \in A\textrm{ or } x\in B\}.

subsection.p: It is important to note in the set-builder notation for A\cup B, the word or is used in the inclusive sense; it includes the case where x is in both A and B.

li.p: A \cup \emptyset = A for any set A.

subsection.p: Frequently, when doing mathematics, we need to establish a universe or set of elements under discussion. For example, the set A = \{x : 81x^4 -16 = 0 \} contains different elements depending on what kinds of numbers we allow ourselves to use in solving the equation 81 x^4 -16 = 0. This set of numbers would be our universe. For example, if the universe is the integers, then A is empty. If our universe is the rational numbers, then A is \{2/3, -2/3\} and if the universe is the complex numbers, then A is \{2/3, -2/3, 2i/3, - 2i/3\}.

statement.p: The universe, or universal set, is the set of all elements under discussion for possible membership in a set. We normally reserve the letter U for a universe in general discussions.

subsection.title: Set Operations and their Venn Diagrams
subsection.p: When working with sets, as in other branches of mathematics, it is often quite useful to be able to draw a picture or diagram of the situation under consideration. A diagram of a set is called a Venn diagram. The universal set U is represented by the interior of a rectangle and the sets by disks inside the rectangle.

notation.description: The complement of A relative to B
The complement of set A relative to the universe.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The complement of A relative to B (notation B - A) is the set of elements that are in B and not in A. That is, B-A=\{x: x\in B \textrm{ and } x\notin A\}. If U is the universal set, then U-A is denoted by A^c and is called simply the complement of A. A^c=\{x\in U : x\notin A\}.

notation.description: The symmetric difference of A and B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The symmetric difference of A and B (denoted by A\oplus B) is the set of all elements that are in A and B but not in both. That is, A \oplus B = (A \cup B) - (A \cap B).

ol.li: A \oplus \emptyset = A and A \oplus A = \emptyset for any set A.
\mathbb{R} \oplus \mathbb{Q} is the set of irrational numbers.

historical.title: Why Venn?
historical.p: Venn diagrams are named after the logician John Venn, who introduced them in a paper in 1880. In his paper, he acknowledged that they were not new. In fact he referred to them as Euler Circles, because the famous mathematician Leonhard Euler (pronounced Oy-ler) introduced them in the 1700's. Don't feel bad for Euler though. He has plenty of other things named after him, including some we see later in this book.

subsection.title: SageMath Note: Sets
subsection.p: To work with sets in Sage, a set is an expression of the form Set(list). By wrapping a list with Set( ), the order of elements appearing in the list and their duplication are ignored. For example, L1 and L2 are two different lists, but notice how as sets they are considered equal:

A \cap B
A \cup B
B \cup A
A \cup C
A - B
B - A
A^c
C^c
A\cap C
A\oplus B

Let A, B, and C be as in Exercise 1, let D = \{3, 2\}, and let E = \{2, 3, 2\}. Determine which of the following are true. Give reasons for your decisions.
A = B
B = C
B = D
E=D
A\cap B = B\cap A
A \cup B = B \cup A
A-B = B-A
A \oplus B = B \oplus A

li.p: False, 0 \in A but not in B.
False, the two sets have no elements in common.
True, the order in which elements are listed is not important.
True, the fact that 2 appears twice in the definition of E doesn't change the fact that it has just two elements.
True, both intesections contain what is common to both A and B.
True, both unions contain numbers that appear in either A or B.

statement.p:
Let U= \{1, 2, 3, . . . , 9\}. Give examples of sets A, B, and C for which:
A\cap (B\cap C)=(A\cap B)\cap C
A\cap (B\cup C)=(A\cap B)\cup (A\cap C)
(A \cup B)^c= A^c\cap B^c
A \cup A^c = U
A \subseteq A\cup B
A\cap B \subseteq A

answer.p: These are all true for any sets A, B, and C.

statement.p:
Let U= \{1, 2, 3, . . . , 9\}. Give examples to illustrate the following facts:
If A \subseteq B and B \subseteq C, then A\subseteq C.
There are sets A and B such that A - B \neq B - A
If U = A\cup B and A \cap B = \emptyset, it always follows that A = U - B.
Suppose that U is an infinite universal set, and A and B are infinite subsets of U. Answer the following questions with a brief explanation.

li.p: No, A^c need not be finite. For example if the universe is all positive integer and A is the set of even positive integers, the its complement is the odd positive integers, which is also infinite.
Yes, since everything that is in A is in the union, A\cup B must be infinite.
No, for example, if A and B are the even and odd positive integer, respectively, then the intersection is empty.
